Award.AwardTitle: XPS: CLCCA: Allocating Heterogeneous Datacenter Hardware to Strategic Agents

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the democratization of cloud computing, increasingly diverse software tasks demand computation from cloud computing. Scalable datacenter computing is a 21st century imperative and energy efficiency is the most pervasive challenge. Increasing capability to extract value from the data deluge requires order-of-magnitude gains in efficiency. While heterogeneous hardware systems provide efficiency, they also complicate resource management. Managing new hardware architectures with economic mechanisms is a qualitatively new approach to mitigate this complexity.

The investigators propose resource allocation mechanisms that encourage truthful participation in datacenters with heterogeneous hardware. Resource allocation pairs hardware with software. Users may explicitly request specific amounts and types of hardware. Or users may define their value for performance, which agents then use to bid for hardware. Both allocation mechanisms rely on the truthful representation of preferences from users. The investigators will quantify inefficiencies arising from strategic behavior in datacenters and will design allocation mechanisms that are robust when strategic agents participate in the system. Women and under-represented students will benefit from this research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project studies resource allocation mechanisms that encourage truthful participation in shared datacenters. Given complex substitution effects between heterogeneous hardware, agents can employ strategic behavior, manipulating or misrepresenting their preferences to benefit at the expense of other agents in the system. The project develops coordinated, interdisciplinary mechanisms in systems architecture, computer science, and economics to guard against strategic behavior, enhance welfare, and reduce risk in heterogeneous hardware systems.

 

The project has produced several major research outcomes. First, the team developed mechanisms to allocate multiple processor resources, such as cache capacity and memory bandwidth, with robust game-theoretic guarantees. When the Cobb-Douglas utility function can model program performance, the algorithm guarantees sharing incentives, envy-freeness, Pareto efficiency, and strategy-proofness in large systems. These results represent rigorous guarantees on system behavior when coordinating the allocation of multiple, complementary hardware resources.  

 

Second, the team has studied mechanisms to manage computational sprints, a class of mechanisms that briefly boost performance by dissipating additional power. For a single processor, the team developed a software run-time system that acquires data during program execution and determines the program periods that benefit most from sprints. For a cluster of many processors, the team develops a sprinting game in which each processor sprints with optimized strategies that produce a mean field equilibrium. In equilibrium, the processors sprint independently but rarely oversubscribe the shared power supply. These results represent significant advances in analyzing online performance for intelligent management and designing game-theoretic mechanisms for decentralized management.

 

Finally, the team has studied mechanisms for workload placement on distributed processor cores. Inspired by cooperative game theory, we operationalize stable matching algorithms for collocating jobs on a single multiprocessor. Inspired by Fisher markets, we operationalize Amdahl’s Law to estimate each job’s parallelizability and define a new utility function. Given this utility function, we design a market for processor cores and derive novel bidding rules that produce an equilibrium, which guarantees optimality, efficiency, and strategy-proofness. These results represent novel interdisciplinary connections between long-standing questions in systems architecture and rigorous theory from algorithmic economics.
